article.title: $pp→A→Zh$ and the wrong-sign limit of the Two-Higgs-Doublet Model

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the production cross sections for a pseudoscalar Higgs boson (A) with a mass of 440 GeV at a center-of-mass energy of 13 TeV as a function of tan β. Which statement best describes the relationship between gluon-fusion and bottom-quark annihilation cross sections for increasing tan β?
choices: Gluon-fusion remains the dominant production mechanism for all values of tan β.
Bottom-quark annihilation becomes increasingly important and eventually surpasses gluon-fusion as tan β increases.
Gluon-fusion and bottom-quark annihilation cross sections decrease at the same rate for increasing tan β.
Both production mechanisms are independent of tan β.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure displays the branching ratio of the pseudoscalar Higgs boson (A) decaying to a Z boson and a light Higgs boson (Zh). What can be concluded about the dominance of the A → Zh decay mode in the wrong-sign limit (red points)?
choices: The A → Zh decay is always suppressed compared to other decay modes.
The A → Zh decay can be dominant even above the tt production threshold, particularly for moderate tan β values.
The A → Zh branching ratio is independent of the pseudoscalar mass.
The A → Zh decay is only dominant for low values of tan β, below the range relevant for the wrong-sign limit.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure investigates the relationship between tan β and cos(β-α) in the 2HDM of type II. What is the significance of the red points clustered along the curved band on the right side of Figure 3(a) and following a specific trend in Figure 3(b)?
choices: They represent the parameter space excluded by current experimental constraints.
They indicate regions where the light Higgs boson properties significantly deviate from SM predictions.
They highlight the parameter space consistent with the wrong-sign limit and a potential excess in  σ(pp → A → Zh → Zbb).
They show regions where the theoretical constraints of the 2HDM are violated.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5 examines the masses of heavier Higgs bosons in the 2HDM of type II and the potential for observing the decay H → ZZ. What implication can be drawn for future searches of H → ZZ if an excess in pp → A → Zh is confirmed?
choices: Such an observation would rule out the wrong-sign limit and the viability of the 2HDM to explain the excess.
It would indicate that the heavy Higgs bosons are too heavy to be detected at the LHC.
The remaining parameter space of the wrong-sign limit would point to a potential signal in H → ZZ observable in the coming years.
The constraints from H → ZZ are irrelevant for the parameter space region where the pp → A → Zh excess is observed.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares the di-photon decay rate (μγγ) and the ZZ production and decay rate (μzz) for the lightest CP-even Higgs boson in the 2HDM of type II. What is the key takeaway regarding the wrong-sign limit from the distribution of data points, particularly the yellow points?
choices: The wrong-sign limit predicts light Higgs boson rates identical to the SM predictions, clustering around the point (1,1).
The wrong-sign limit is already excluded by the precise measurements of the light Higgs boson couplings.
An excess in σ(pp → A → Zh → Zbb) within the wrong-sign limit would result in observable deviations from SM light Higgs boson rates in μγγ and μzz.
The wrong-sign limit only affects the heavy Higgs bosons and has no impact on the light Higgs boson properties.
